record.text:
At the CSS WG meeting, we're discussing possibly natively doing fit-text in CSS. Send us your use cases (with screenshots/links)!

Do you ever need to fit multi-line text?
Do you ever need to fit non-text inline elements (e.g. icons)?
Do you adjust font-size, letter-spacing, or both?
CSS masonry layouts have resolved to use grid-lanes as the syntax

record.text:
Maybe a better question is:

What doesnt a web element know?

external.description: As Miriam Suzanne says "components know stuff," but like, how much stuff?
external.title: Web components know about the user, device, variables, layout and more ¬∑ October 30, 2025

value.text:
What'd I miss?

components know:
- user stuff
- device stuff
- app stuff
- design stuff
- what stuff is in them
- what stuff they're inside
- etc

It's amazing how much a component can know on the web, and I'm going to try and list it all out. Help me ü§ì

#CSS
nerdy.dev/components-c...

external.title: Web components know about the user, device, variables, layout and more ¬∑ October 30, 2025

embed.alt: Adam Argyle talking about a job interview where they gave him the option to pick vanilla JavaScript or React. He picked vanilla, but it was a trick question, and they wanted React. He then used a lot of native APIs that they had never seen before, but instead of being impressed, they judged him for taking the time to bother learning them.

value.text:
Didn't plan it this way, but nothing much scarier than talking about getting a job in tech these days üò±

Check out my full convo with @nerdy.dev about his recent experience looking for a new job:

external.title: Ex-Masonry Display Type Keyword Poll

record.text:
There's a new #CSS Working Group poll to get feedback on different names for the infamous 'Pinterest' layout. 

- Since it uses many of the grid-* properties, `grid` will be in the name somewhere
- We don't use metaphors in CSS names, so `masonry` is not listed here

docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1F...

external.title: Ex-Masonry Display Type Keyword Poll

record.text:
There‚Äôs a new type of CSS scroll-state query coming: ‚Äúscrolled‚Äù.

This one remembers the last direction you scrolled into, which you can use to build ‚Äúhidey bars‚Äù: when scrolling down (or having scrolled down), the hidey bar hides itself. When then scrolling back up, the hidey bar reveals itself.

embed.alt: Recording of the demo. Find the link in the next message.

embed.alt: An interface displays a salmon-colored dashed-outlined box. Inside, a square blue box with a smile emoji in its center rests at the top left corner. A mouse cursor hovers over the salmon box, clicks and holds. The blue box smoothly transitions to the opposite corner of the container while the emoji switches to having heart eyes. Controls below the area change the transition axis and dimensions of the blue box to demonstrate how it always transitions exactly to the other side.

record.text:
Container queries and CSS make it simple to smoothly transition an element to the other side of its parent container without knowing exact dimensions or distance.

Read more in my latest post: ryanmulligan.dev/blog/transit...

embed.alt: An interface displays a salmon-colored dashed-outlined box. Inside, a square blue box with a smile emoji in its center rests at the top left corner. A mouse cursor hovers over the salmon box, clicks and holds. The blue box smoothly transitions to the opposite corner of the container while the emoji switches to having heart eyes. Controls below the area change the transition axis and dimensions of the blue box to demonstrate how it always transitions exactly to the other side.

Nest ::view-transition-group pseudo-elements within each other to restore effects such as clipping during a view transition.
external.title: Prevent clipping issues (and more) in view transitions by using nested view transition groups  |  CSS and UI  |  Chrome for Developers

record.text:
A new View Transitions-related feature we shipped in Chrome 140 is the ability to nest ::view-transition-group() pseudos.

This is useful for retaining visual effects such as clipping, move elements as part of a group, etc.

developer.chrome.com/docs/css-ui/...

external.title: Prevent clipping issues (and more) in view transitions by using nested view transition groups  |  CSS and UI  |  Chrome for Developers
external.description: Nest ::view-transition-group pseudo-elements within each other to restore effects such as clipping during a view transition.

record.text:
‚ú® New article ‚ú®

Are we at the start of a new era?

Chrome 140 introduced CSS Typed Arithmetic. It might seem like a minor change, but I believe it's huge as it opens the door to countless new possibilities and a whole new era of Computational CSS.

What do you think?

value.text:
‚ú® I just published a brand-new blog post about a modern CSS feature!

But, honestly, I‚Äôm still on the fence about it. üòÖ

In this post, I‚Äôll dig into the gnarly issue I ran into, and share three possible workarounds. Along the way, you‚Äôll learn a bunch about the CSS cascade and specificity!

record.text:

You set up a "follower" element and dynamically update the anchor on an event/state. Surprisingly simple and effective.

Read more with demos!:

images.alt: Screenshot of a DevTools trace showing the a custom property cannot be animated on the compositor.

record.text:
Nothing has changed here. Custom properties currently still animate on the main thread.

You can see this in codepen.io/bramus/pen/w... after hitting the ‚ÄúAdd Jank‚Äù button, or by doing a DevTools trace.

Please star issues.chromium.org/issues/40890... to signal interest into getting this changed.

embed.alt: Recording of a demo that uses document-scoped and element-scoped transitions. When using the latter, the blue dot remains clipped by the scope and the popover remains visible on top of the scope.

record.text:
If you thought we were done with View Transitions, guess again!

A feature Chrome is working on, is ‚ÄúScoped View Transitions‚Äù, which allow you to scope a VT to a subtree of the DOM.

This unlocks things like concurrent transitions and prevents layering issues.

developer.chrome.com/blog/scoped-...

embed.alt: Recording of a demo that uses document-scoped and element-scoped transitions. When using the latter, the blue dot remains clipped by the scope and the popover remains visible on top of the scope.
